channel.title: CNN.com - World
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 Cable News Network LP, LLLP.

image.title: CNN.com - World
image.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

item.title: Soap opera helping Rwandans heal
item.description: Romance. Suspense. Good versus evil. On the surface, Rwandan radio soap opera "Musekeweya," or "New Dawn," feels familiar. Like a Rwandan "Romeo and Juliet," it tells the story of lovers from two different villages at odds with each other.

item.title: The week in 34 photos
Look at me! 25 selfies of the week
CNN reporter hit with tear gas
item.description: CNN's Rafael Romo struggles to report on a violent protest in Mexico as police release tear gas.

item.title: Sesay driven to tell girls' story
item.description: Isha Sesay explains why the Nigerian girls, once seemingly so close to release, still haven't come home.

item.title: Reporters' photos on the scene
Aleppo's children need protection
item.description: Children living in the Syrian city of Aleppo watch the sky. Not for signs of winter's approach, although the cold winds are already blowing, but for the barrel bombs, mortars and shellfire they know will not distinguish between military targets and their families' homes.

item.title: How to respond to assertive Russia
item.description: Last week, the news broke that Russian aircraft will commence patrolling the skies over the Caribbean Sea and Gulf of Mexico. Washington reacted mildly to Defense Minister Sergey Shoigu's announcement. The U.S. State Department questioned Moscow's rationale for operating off North American coastlines while insisting that such flights "must be consistent with international law and conducted with due regard for the rights of other nations and the safety of other aircraft and of vessels."

item.title: The man of the millennium?
item.description: Let's hear it for "the man of the moment, the man of the millennium."

item.title: Jailed for 'Hunger Games' salute
item.description: What would Katniss do?

item.title: China in love with private education
item.description: In China it's known as gaokao -- the college entrance exams -- and for most young people it dictates the course of a life.

item.title: Watch landmark Cold War series
item.description: The struggle between communism and capitalism defined the second half of the 20th Century. The Cold War pitted east against west, pushing the world to the brink of nuclear war.

item.title: In photos: History of the Cold War
Human face carved in gemstone
item.description: Experimental Chinese jeweler stumbles on something mysterious.

item.title: Extreme sports: Pushing the limits
Eerie geometry of everyday life
item.description: Photographer shoots series of eerie symmetries captured from above

item.title: Bizarre creatures from the deep
item.description: A portrait photographer has captured sea creatures in gorgeous detail.

item.title: 39 amazing sports photos
Greatest stage spectacles on Earth
item.description: New tech is transforming concert experiences into eye-popping extravaganzas

item.title: Stash of stars' photos unearthed
item.description: It all started with some boxes that had not been opened for 80 years.

item.title: The $50 earthquake alarm
item.description: In September 1985 a devastating earthquake measuring 8.1 on the Richter Scale smashed into Mexico City killing 10,000 people and leaving parts of the city in ruins.

item.title: Surf queen: 'Water is my office'
item.description: For the millions of us who sit at desks all day, Carissa Moore's description of her workplace might sound a little cruel.

item.title: Big cash for old bags?
item.description: Just don't expect thrift store prices.

item.title: Jamaica: Small island, big heart
item.description: Travel photos open windows to the unknown.

item.title: Drone snaps superyachts
item.description: Drones are revolutionizing how we capture many sports, but does anything come close to these shots of superyachts at sea?

item.title: 'I used to see my dad in my dreams'
item.description: Maram scrunches up her little nose and pauses as she remembers. The eight-year-old was daddy's favorite.

item.title: Parents of missing 43 want justice
item.description: In parental torment over what became of his son and 42 other missing Mexican students, Isrrael Galindo rejects official accounts they apparently were massacred. He hopes that somehow his son and the others are still alive.

item.title: World's spectacular fountains
item.description: Not content to simply swim in it, fill balloons with it, shoot it at bystanders during massive water fights or mix it with whiskey, people never cease to find amazing ways to make water even more incredible than it already is.

item.title: Dress like a world leader
item.description: China's online marketplace Taobao is offering buyers the chance to look like a world leader -- for less than $30.

item.title: Famous poet's manuscript found
item.description: A notebook full of work-in-progress versions of some of Dylan Thomas's key poems has been rediscovered more than 70 years after the poet's mother-in-law ordered it to be burnt.

item.title: 'Starry Night' bike path opens
item.description: An artist in the Netherlands has created a brilliant tribute to Vincent van Gogh -- a bike path that glows in the dark.

item.title: 80 spectacular travel photos
item.description: Each day, CNN producers select a user-submitted photo to be our Travel Photo of the Day. Click through the gallery above to see stunning shots from around the world, and be sure to come back every day for a new image.

item.title: Surf's up! Catching waves in Dakar
item.description: In Dakar, a growing community of surf lovers are taking advantage of the warm weather, year-round waves and cheap flights.

item.title: Haunting beauty of moldy photographs
item.description: South Korean artist Seung-Hwan Oh creates beautiful portraits by letting mold grow on film.

item.title: Fashion models strut at U.N.
item.description: It's one of the more unusual places to hold a fashion show: the United Nations.

item.title: Kidjo: 'Do I LOOK like I have Ebola?'
item.description: It was in a New York cab. That's when Grammy Award-winning signer Angelique Kidjo realized the extent that "fear-bola" had spread.

item.title: 'Living painting' grows before you
item.description: Painting on a wet canvas, this artist films his works as the colors swirl and bleed into evolving forms.

item.title: Sex museums: A global guide
item.description: The subject of erotica has a way of making people uncomfortable.

item.title: China's craziest marriage proposals
item.description: One man bought 99 new iPhones and arranged them into the shape of a heart.

item.title: Man: I was 'idiot' to surf dead whale
item.description: An Australian man who "surfed" a floating whale carcass surrounded by sharks has admitted that he was an "idiot" to attempt the foolhardy feat.

item.title: The Asian definition of beauty
item.description: If department stores in Asia are the battle ground for its emerging middle classes, then the cosmetics counter is its front line.

item.title: Paradise seeks beach-goers
item.description: Seychelles has long been a must-visit destination for jet-setters from all over the world. Tourists come from Europe, the Middle East and Asia to unwind in the sun. But not all the hosts can afford to be so relaxed.

item.title: What does your country smell like?
item.description: UK's Heathrow Airport pairs destinations with fragrances to evoke long distance travel.

item.title: Monuments lost to conflict
item.description: All these astonishing buildings were destroyed by recent wars.

item.title: Is ISIS inspiring Australia attacks?
item.description: Muslim community leaders in Australia say sectarian tensions are soaring, as radicalized Sunni youth, inspired by ISIS, seek to import the religious conflicts wracking the Middle East.

item.title: 8 ways to love a Cape Cod oasis
item.description: Provincetown is an oasis with the kind of light that inspires artists and writers, a town at the tip of Massachusetts' Cape Cod that celebrates the LGBT community.

item.title: Remember when this was sexy?
item.description: You wouldn't necessarily expect a blockbuster exhibition on women's clothing to open with a giant image of a naked lady.

item.title: Tourists head for 'Death Railway'
item.description: This haunting site recalls thousands of lost lives during WWII.

item.title: Children caught in ISIS slaughter
item.description: ISIS militants killed more than 300 members of a Sunni tribe in a recent series of executions, the Iraqi government said Monday.

item.title: Bars, coke, sex: Life of HK banker
item.description: A British banker reveals the darker side of Hong Kong, scene of a recent grisly double-murder, where he and colleagues went on three-day cocaine benders. Leaving the city saved his life.

item.title: Exploring deep space's double
item.description: Touching down on the otherworldly landscape that stars as a distant planet in one of the year's most hyped movies.

item.title: SEAL commander to SEALs: Seal it
item.description: The head of Naval Warfare Special Command had warned Navy SEALs against betraying their promise to maintain secrecy just days ahead of a SEAL's "60 Minutes" interview defending his publication of details from the Osama bin Laden mission.

item.title: The man who ran from genocide
item.description: He was dubbed the "man without a country" who found he was at home running in one of athletics' toughest events.

item.title: Medieval doodles full of humor
item.description: My personal favorite is this. At the top of a page of angular medieval text -- full of theological extrapolations and religious devotion -- is a cartoon of a deadpan dog.

item.title: The last Costa Concordia victim
item.description: Nearly three years after the Costa Concordia cruise ship ran aground off Italy's Giglio Island, the remains of the final victim have been recovered.

item.title: Sistine Chapel gets makeover
item.description: High above the altar in the Vatican's Sistine Chapel, Michelangelo's masterpiece fresco is being seen in a new light.

item.title: Spanish town defined by dining
item.description: Global gourmets frequently place San Sebastian atop their culinary bucket list -- and that's before they've tried the local tapas.

item.title: 'Most sensitive kilometer on Earth'
item.description: Tension in Jerusalem is at its greatest since the end of the second intifada, or Palestinian uprising, 10 years ago -- stoked by a rash of what some call hate crimes and others acts of terror.

item.title: Grisly murders stun Hong Kong
item.description: A foreign man, whom local media identified as British, has been arrested after the bodies of two women were found at a high-end Hong Kong apartment -- one of them hidden inside a suitcase.

item.title: Drone-maker takes 'selfies' to skies
item.description: What comes in a white cardboard box, weighs little more than a kilogram and can be purchased in a few clicks from Amazon?

item.title: Extravagant presidential palaces
item.description: A look through some of the most exquisite residences of leaders from across the world.

item.title: They really don't like each other
item.description: Barack Obama and Benjamin Netanyahu haven't liked each other for years -- they just aren't bothering to hide it anymore.

item.title: Tiny gaping mouth wins top photo
item.description: The true test of patience is peering for hours into a microscope waiting for a rotifer to open its mouth so you can snap a quick photo.

item.title: 5 amazing places in Iran
item.description: It might not be on everyone's travel radar, but Iran has a well-worn tourist circuit, encompassing attractions in the ancient cities of Shiraz and Isfahan.

item.title: The last kings of Africa
item.description: In Africa, royalty is an endangered species. Alfred Weidinger is on a mission to photograph the last remaining.

item.title: Worst public transit for women?
item.description: Alarming findings related to women's safety have come to light with the release of a Thomson Reuters Foundation survey that looks at harassment on public transportation systems in the world's largest cities.

item.title: Photos that defy perspective
item.description: It all started when she kissed the Great Sphinx of Giza.

item.title: To North Korea, from 'human scum'
item.description: In North Korea's utopian society, the very words "human rights" do not need to exist -- because it's so perfect, the regime maintains.

item.title: Zakaria: Problem within Islam
item.description: When the news flashed last week that a man had shot and killed a Canadian soldier in front of the National War Memorial in Canada, what most people were wondering -- but not saying out loud -- was, "Is it another radical Muslim?"

item.title: What an Ebola survivor looks like
item.description: Getty photographer John Moore took beautiful portraits of Ebola survivors

item.title: 6 things about Iran hostage crisis
item.description: It has been 35 years since a group of Iranian students stormed the U.S. Embassy in Tehran and took a group of Americans hostage. You have seen this story play out in movies like "Argo" and shows like "Homeland," but here are six things about the Iran hostage crisis that you may not have known.

item.title: King Tut's 'virtual autopsy' surprises
item.description: King Tutankhamun's golden, mummified remains tell only a partial story of an ancient Egyptian boy king who died under mysterious circumstances.

item.title: Scott's Antarctica notebook found
item.description: A century-old photographer's notebook has been found in the ice at one of Robert Falcon Scott's expedition bases in Antarctica.

item.title: The factory people pay to see
item.description: At Volkswagen's Dresden plant, car manufacture becomes a public performance.

item.title: ISIS threatens priceless heritage
item.description: ISIS is threatening priceless cultural artifacts, particularly in the ancient city of Hatra, says the director of the Iraq National Museum in Baghdad.

item.title: The green sports car
item.description: Zero to sixty miles in 2.5 seconds. 887 horse power. And a price tag of $1 million.

item.title: And the best airline food is...
item.description: There can't be many people who choose their flight on the quality of its catering -- but those who do should check out these awards.

item.title: Diwali celebrations light up India
item.description: Around the world, Indians are celebrating the festival of lights with fireworks and candles. Here's a look at some of this week's India festivities.

item.title: This parasite keeps millions poor
item.description: One of the most debilitating medical conditions in sub-Saharan Africa isn't fatal. In fact, it's easily curable. The culprit is small, but its impact is big. The chigoe flea, more commonly known as a jigger, typically burrows itself into the feet and hands. It prevents millions of children from attending school, stops farmers from working their land, and makes walking all but unbearable.

item.title: 5 can't-miss Tanzania moments
item.description: Tanzania is far more than just a spot to climb the world's tallest freestanding mountain.

item.title: Boko Haram victim: I cried for help
item.description: With every attack by Islamist militants in northern Nigeria, Daniel Ayuba relives a nightmare.

item.title: How Victorians dressed for death
item.description: 150 years ago, you really had to wear your grief on your sleeve.

item.title: Pay off poachers, save wildlife
item.description: In Namibia, the question of who owns the wildlife has often been fraught with difficulties.

item.title: Only 6 northern white rhinos left
item.description: Unique? Suni was only one of seven northern whites left in the world. Now he's dead.

item.title: Ebola fears cripple safaris
item.description: With travel to Africa poised to hit all-time highs in 2014, a drop-off in travel bookings was the last thing the continent's lucrative safari industry thought it would be facing going into 2015.

item.title: Clues to Stone Age mating
item.description: DNA from a 45,000-year-old leg bone is giving scientists a better idea of when modern humans first started mating with Neanderthals.

item.title: 10 pics to change how you see China
item.description: Contemporary Chinese art is a formidable force in today's art market and a thorny jungle for the uninitiated. Expert Wu Hung, the founder of the Center for the Art of East Asia at the University of Chicago, has chosen 10 stunning works that can systematically introduce China's recent art movements and must-know avant-garde artists from the 1970s to the 2000s.

item.title: World's worst airport in 2014 is ...
item.description: After topping the notorious list three years in a row, Manila's Ninoy Aquino International Airport is no longer the world's worst airport.

item.title: And baby makes 4
item.description: April, come she will. Or he. While we don't yet know the gender of the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge's second baby, we now know the royal couple will become parents in April 2015.

item.title: Daredevils risk lives for perfect shot
item.description: Cityscapes are usually breathtaking, but finding a good vantage point in a new town can be tough.

item.title: What a shot! 35 amazing sports photos
What we learn from ISIS magazine
item.description: ISIS is looking to take over a good chunk of the Middle East -- if not the entire Muslim world, write Peter Bergen and Emily Schneider.

item.title: Mysterious space mission ends
item.description: Whatever it was doing up in space, we may never know, but the U.S. Air Force's unmanned X-37B space plane returned to Earth this week, with still no details from the military on the nearly two-year mission.

item.title: Photographer battles stereotypes
item.description: Kurbanjan Samat, a 32-year-old Uyghur photographer, wants to dispel the stereotypes he says many Chinese hold about people from his home region -- an ethnically diverse province in China's far west.

item.title: Rocket-powered toy in stratosphere
item.description: A British team is set to launch a 3D-printed, rocket-powered space plane into the stratosphere. CNN's Jim Boulden report

item.title: Why a feminist converted to Islam
item.description: I am a Muslim, but I wasn't always. I converted to Islam in November 2001, two months after 9/11.

item.title: Attack kills 45 at volleyball game
item.description: At least 45 people were killed and 60 others wounded when a suicide bomber attacked a crowd watching a volleyball match in Afghanistan.

item.title: 'Smart Sewage' could spot epidemics
item.description: Valuable insight into our health is lurking beneath our city streets. "We can reveal the invisible in a city. The underworld we don't see every day," says architect Carlo Ratti.

item.title: Wiping out polio, country by country
item.description: Viewing this on a mobile device? Go here

item.title: Optics shed new light on the brain
item.description: Karl Deisseroth of Stanford University on his groundbreaking research in brain mapping.

item.title: The week in 34 photos
African sushi shakes up Japan
item.description: The flashing neon advertising signs and crowded crosswalks of Tokyo may not resemble the slow suburban settlement of Maseru -- the capital of the tiny mountain kingdom of Lesotho in southern Africa. But the two countries are now being linked by an unlikely dish: trout.

item.title: Hermits and where they dwell
item.description: Deep in the untouched areas of Ukraine and Russia live men who have decided to leave human establishments and live isolated in nature.

item.title: Can we pull elephants from brink?
item.description: Richard Leakey says Angelina Jolie is planning a movie about fight against elephant poaching, but need to end the ivory trade that is bringing elephants closer to extinction is immediate

item.title: Japanese 'black widow' questioned
item.description: A 67-year-old woman who reportedly received millions in life insurance money from at least five of her previous partners has been arrested on suspicion of poisoning her last husband with cyanide -- the latest high-profile case in Japan involving so-called "black widows."

item.title: Teachers riot in Mexico
item.description: With little developments in the mystery of 43 missing students in Guerrero, Mexico, the community is outraged.

item.title: 'Any minute we could be shot'
item.description: Joseph Mathenge details how he risked his life to cover the Westgate Mall attack in Kenya last year.

item.title: Great white caught near beach
item.description: A 2.5 meter long great white shark was found tangled in nets surrounding one of Sydney's busiest beaches.

item.title: Starving and scared in East Ukraine
item.description: Spent bullets gleam in the wintry sun, sandbags sag over deserted trenches, and tanks slowly rust. The fight for control of eastern Ukraine is taking its toll on the area's residents.

item.title: Female police recruits' virginity test
item.description: Women joining Indonesia's police are subjected to invasive virginity tests, human rights activists say.

item.title: Astonishing photo-realistic portraits
item.description: The images you are about to see may shock or confound you. When portraiture looks this realistic, it can be hard to accept that what you see is just paint on a canvas, or ink scratches on a page.

item.title: How to paint a portrait in 54 seconds
item.description: In a series of 9 gorgeous time-lapse vines, world-renowned portrait artist Jonathon Yeo gives a master-class on how to paint like a pro.

item.title: Robot prints artist's selfie. In blood
item.description: This is a selfie made of blood. Yes, real, straight-from-veins-of-a-human blood. The human you're looking at is Ted Lawson, an artist living in Brooklyn. These are his first blood paintings. Lawson created the works for an upcoming exhibition, The Map Is Not the Territory, opening September 11 at the Joseph Gross Gallery in NYC, and it should be noted that he didn't originally set out to paint with his vital fluids. Then again, who does?

item.title: Father, sons leave Germany to fight ISIS
item.description: Qassim Shesho fled Iraq for Germany in 1990. Now, he's back with two of his sons to defend his land, family and religion from the terrorist group.

item.title: Cyclists find baby in storm drain
item.description: In Australia, a newborn baby was found in a storm drain, up to five days after he was abandoned there.

item.title: Iran nuclear talks going down to the wire
item.description: International negotiators in Vienna are scrambling to reach a deal on Iran's nuclear program, with media in Tehran suggesting a comprehensive agreement by Monday's deadline is "impossible."

item.title: U.S. expands combat role in Afghanistan
item.description: President Obama has decided to extend the combat role of U.S. forces in Afghanistan into 2015. CNN's Erin McPike reports.

item.title: 2 reported dead after 5.9 quake hits southwest China
item.description: A magnitude-5.9 earthquake struck a remote region of southwestern China, reportedly killing at least two people and causing a stampede at a primary school.

item.title: Strong earthquake shakes Japan
item.description: A strong earthquake shook central Japan on Saturday night, injuring several people as their homes collapsed in a village west of Nagano, an official said.

item.title: Arrested in case of missing Mexican students
item.description: A top local police official in Mexico was arrested in connection with the disappearance of 43 college students, authorities said.

item.title: Building a brighter future for Guatemala's kids
item.description: Growing up in Guatemala, Juan Pablo Romero Fuentes watched many of his peers succumb to drugs, gangs and crime.

item.title: Russia accuses West of seeking regime change in Moscow
item.description: With tensions simmering over the deadly crisis in Ukraine, Russia has accused the West of seeking regime change in Moscow, prompting renewed comparisons with the Cold War era.

item.title: 3 accused of plot to kill Israeli minister
item.description: The Israeli military said Friday it arrested three Palestinians from the West Bank and charged them in an alleged plot to assassinate Israeli Foreign Minister Avigdor Lieberman.

item.title: Starving and scared in Ukraine
item.description: Yuri Poznychenko has lived in the village of Stepanovka, close to Ukraine's border with Russia, all his life.

item.title: UK bans self-professed dating expert
item.description: A self-professed American dating expert who has said he feels like the most hated man in the world has been banned from entering another country -- Britain.

item.title: Russia plans bomber flights near U.S.
item.description: Russia plans to send long-range bombers to patrol the western Atlantic and eastern Pacific waters, the nation's defense minister said, amid escalating tensions with the West over Ukraine.

item.title: Honduran beauty queen killed
item.description: A Honduran beauty queen and her sister were found dead Wednesday, police said, and the sister's boyfriend and another man have been arrested.

item.title: Mexico protesters throw Molotovs
item.description: Protesters demanding justice for 43 missing students started throwing Molotov cocktails in Mexico City's main square.

item.title: 5 Guantanamo detainees transferred
item.description: Five detainees at Guantanamo Bay were transferred to the nations of Slovakia or Georgia as part of the U.S. plan to reduce the facility's population of detainees who were suspected of terrorism after the September 11, 2001, attacks, officials said Thursday.

item.title: 5 killed in synagogue attack
item.description: A college trip to Israel changed rabbi Kalman Levine's life, his childhood best friend Shimon Kraft remembers.

item.title: Who else remains captive by ISIS?
item.description: The latest ISIS video showing beheaded American aid worker Peter Kassig differs from the jihadists' prior murderous tapings in that they didn't threaten to kill another Western hostage.

item.title: ISIS 'cub' fighter, 15, saved by father
item.description: The first time "Yasir" saw a beheading he didn't eat for two days, repulsed by the scene, not the actual act. But ISIS gave him such purpose his father had to trick him into leaving.

item.title: 'Any minute we could be shot'
item.description: Joseph Mathenge hadn't planned to be at Westgate Mall in Nairobi, Kenya in September 2013, when gunmen -- now associated with Islamist terror group Al Shabaab -- infiltrated the shopping center and started shooting en masse in a blitz that resulted in 67 deaths.

item.title: The $.30 kit that could end malaria
item.description: It's an entirely preventable disease, and when diagnosed early, it's easily treatable. Yet Malaria still claims hundreds of thousands of lives each year.

item.title: Soap opera helping Rwandans heal
item.description: Romance. Suspense. Good versus evil. On the surface, Rwandan radio soap opera "Musekeweya," or "New Dawn," feels familiar. Like a Rwandan "Romeo and Juliet," it tells the story of lovers from two different villages at odds with each other.
